job_title: Mental Health Technician in Minneapolis, MN

job_title: Behavior Technician in Waite Park, MN
pros: You can get good experience learning what children on the autism spectrum are like, learning some strategies to handle difficult behaviors.
cons: Know what you're getting yourself into. Much of what you will be doing is "obedience training". Teaching kids to follow commands without giving them context to fully understand why they should be listening to you, only that since you're an authority figure they should listen. Many adults who have gone through this kind of therapy have called it harmful if not traumatizing. While the kids are amazing and easy to love, you have to consider whether or not you actually think this is what is best for them. While it might not be as black and white as it is made out to be, it is up to you to ask yourself if you believe that this will really help them in the future.

job_title: Mental Health Practitioner in Minneapolis, MN
pros: I love the people I worked with and I’m so grateful for the awesome clients I got to work with.
cons: The company is growing so fast that there isn’t enough oversight or building current programs.

job_title: Direct Support Professional in Richfield, MN
pros: - flexible work settings and schedules
cons: pay is lower but the staff are great

job_title: Mental Health Technician in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Amazing clients and supportive staff. Great opportunities to work your way up!
cons: Low paying and little paid time off

job_title: Behavior Technician in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The coworkers are amazing. They are all so kind and compassionate and supportive, which is very necessary in this job. It is also amazing seeing kids grow and learn.
cons: If you are a behavior technician (i.e. don't have your degree in psych or related field) then you are paid significantly less than Behavior practitioners for the exact same job. Even sometimes working harder than BPs and was not rewarded for that. You will be written up if you get sick, even if it is COVID, or the flu. Even if you're in the hospital and provide proof, HR will still write you up. This also affects your hiring bonus, which nobody told any of the employees. So many people quit under a year, there is so much staff turnover. Management and HR have horrible absence policies, emergency weather policies, etc. They took PTO hours from employees even when the whole clinic was closed due to snow and there was no work. Full time workers do not get sick days, it must come from your PTO if you've accrued it, otherwise it's a tally against you and that's only the first 40 hours. Working with kids so many people got sick and were afraid to miss work which puts children at risk so they'd come to work so ill. You only get a 30 minute lunch break and they don't give you time to go to the bathroom throughout the day, you just have to ask someone to watch your kid for you and sometimes that's impossible. Many times treatment plans are not updated so it makes it hard to do documentation. Definitely experienced behaviors from clients which was hard but they do tell you about that in the interview, so yeah. Made really good friends, but suffered everyday and was overworked overwhelmed and underpaid.

job_title: Behaviroal Health Practitioner in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
Flexible scheduling for exempt employees
Positive team culture
Interaction with clients
On-going training and productive team meetings
One hour computer/task time in the morning prior to clients arriving, and about 30 mins after clients leave, and sometimes during the day when clients go to other services.
cons:
Structurally not the best design for kids 
Over-crowded classrooms, hallways, bathrooms, and break rooms. 
No close parking for everyone- about a 15 min walk from the designated parking lot. 
Fast turn over for staff
Inconsistent teaching styles
Lack of employee appreciation
Lack of communication 
Repetitive issues that are not addressed
Improper sanitization/infection control and food handling.
30 min break which often feels like 20 mins because it takes time to settle in (microwaving food, clocking in/out, relocating personal items from room to room, using the bathroom, walking across the large building to get to the preferred break space).
Group time is often stressful and disengaging. 
Daily billing/documentation is tedious.
Scheduling staff and clients could be done more fairly by using a consistent template that gets changed every once in a while to prevent favoritism among teachers and clients.

job_title: Behavior Practitioner II in Eden Prairie, MN
pros: Decent pay, fun kids to “work” with.
cons: Not even close to ABA. Fraser’s “ABA” program consists of a run of the mill curriculum which does not individualize the goals or targets to the client’s individual needs. This violates the BACB code of ethics in at least 2 ways, and is by definition abusive in practice, as it serves the company’s financial interests more so than the interests of the child and family of the child. If you want to actually work to help children learn new skills in ways that are beneficial to themselves, don’t try to do it here or you will be ostracized for doing so.

job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Bloomington, MN
pros: The team is supportive, and open to support coworkers in understanding daily task. Supervisors are really good at not micromanaging, and understand the importance of self care. cons: A con would be the lack of diversity, and the fight to have proactive trainings on diversity and inclusion. This is specific to both case management and Fraser wide. The hope is that now that the BIPOC staff has received support from our non-BIPOC staff diversity, inclusion, and anti-racism will be taken more seriously moving forward (this is only relevant to Fraser Wide)

job_title: Clinical Program Assistant in Woodbury, MN
pros: This is a good place to get some exposure to working in mental health, particularly with children and in Autism services. They have flexible schedules and depending on your location parking might be free. Other employees tend to be very nice and working with children is extremely rewarding. I have no doubt that taking a part-time job here really helped me develop skills for working with children in mental health and gave me an edge with getting a good internship for my counseling internship (which has since turned into a great offer for full-time post degree employment).
cons: Despite the companies claim that they offer career advancement it is very hard to get full-time employment as a non-licensed employee. I received Clinical Program Assistant of the Month and repeatedly asked to be put up to full-time. However, Instead, they stood on more employees for my room. My understanding is they are reluctant to give employees full time because then they would have to offer benefits. Pay is also extremely low and the work is very hard and intense. I considered returning after graduating with my MA in counseling but I can make much more in private practice and the work is much less taxing. This is a great place to get some experience and work part-time as a student but I wouldn't recommend it for anyone needing a living wage and work-life balance. The MHP 1 and 2's were constantly overwhelmed and could barely keep up with paperwork. If my memory is correct I was started at 13.75 an hour with a bachelor's degree in early childhood education and most of an MA in psychology. It's super fun and I miss the kids but I can't see going back even with my counseling license unless they make significant changes.

review_title: Fraser is a great place to work
job_title: Developmental Trainee in Minneapolis, MN

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Richfield, MN
pros:
Wonderful people to support with a wide variety of abilities and disabilities.  The guardians/teams are genuinely appreciative of all that the people who are supporting their loved ones do for the,  Beautiful homes to work in that have obviously had a lot of money invested to make the homes accessible, warm and comfortable for those living in them. 
High PTO benefits that are flexible to be used for holidays, pick time, vacation, etc.
cons:
No work/life balance.  Work is first.  You are expected to pick up the phone 24 hours a day.  Even if coverage is arranged, it ultimately falls on you to make sure the situation is dealt with correctly.   
No additional compensation for on-call duties.  No additional compensation for emergency direct care support.   You will be called for non-emergency reasons, by policy, regardless of the time.  
You will always be in 'emergency-mode' rather than being able to proactively address a situation.  Support from management has extremely slow turn around, if any support is given, making the emergency-mode cycle continue.    
Management has an "Us Vs. Them" attitude, discouraging questions or conversation to provide "a united front against" their employees.   
No holiday pay besides using PTO.  No additional pay if working on a holiday (PTO cannot be used if working the holiday).

review_title: Poor management and no proper PPE use
job_title: Direct Support Professional in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The clients were great to work with and they would work around my school schedule.
cons: No PPE requirements were actually enforced due to COVID, multiple employees getting COVID and going on leave and no protection.

job_title: Behavior Pracritioner I in Eagan, MN

cons: Pay is awful especially given the intense nature if the job. Management does not care about staff. Corporate staff is invested in the bottom line far more than the clients served. You’ll work hard and be thanked minimally.

review_title: Fraser has provided many opportunities to grow in my journey as a therapist!

review_title: For more accurate reviews, go to Indeed.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Richfield, MN
pros: Coworkers are wonderful people and really care about clients.
cons: Fraser does benefit many families but it is run as a for profit company rather than a non profit and does not value it's employees. The CEO receives a yearly bonus of almost $70,000 while many people in entry level positions are earning just $13 an hour (about $21,000 without any deductions.) These are the employees typically working directly with clients in group homes or in the Fraser School. It is my opinion that they deserve to be compensated at a higher level for the hard work they are doing. The board of directors is comprised of donors who have contributed large sums rather than representative of the community that Fraser is serving. Overall, this moves the focus to the donors and what Fraser can do to earn more money instead of focusing on what can be done to benefit the community and the clients we serve. Recently, a number of reviews were posted from people in management, HR, and employees who have been with Fraser for a number of years. I feel that this is skewing the rating given that many of these ratings were posted within the last few weeks and the rating was then added to the Fraser website. I have enjoyed working at Fraser and interacting with clients, but it is frustrating to hear Fraser talk about how much they value employees and clients while at the same time not reflecting that in their actions.

job_title: Director in Bloomington, MN
pros: Fraser is a leader in the disability services world.  We have a culture that puts the individuals we serve first and we also offer a supportive team in which to work!  As a Director at Fraser I have been a part of business decisions to continue services despite financial deficits due to low reimbursement rates, thus demonstrating how mission driven this organization really is.  We also have many opportunities for career advancement with career paths being drawn up and expanded frequently.  I actually started as a developmental trainee in our clinical autism program and have moved up to more direct care, then supervision, then program management, and now director over the years.  Fraser has a robust PTO benefit and is one of the only organizations that has been able to consistently contribute up to 5% of an eligible employee's annual salary without an employee-required match in retirement benefits.  We continue to grow and are able to give annual pay-for-performance salary increases due to our strong presence and excellent services provided in the community.
cons: I honestly cannot think of a con about working at Fraser!  I feel grateful every day for finding Fraser and joining this great organization so soon out of college.

job_title: Human Resources Representative in Richfield, MN
pros: Fraser is truly an awesome company. You can tell that many of the people working here care much more about the type of work they do rather than just collecting a paycheck. Lots of the culture is centered around the value of the work and my experience has been surrounded by tons of very talented professionals who do a good job of not just telling you how to do something, but helping you learn
cons: With growing so quickly, there's always growing pains. Lots of new positions means lots of movement internally and externally from the company which can make it feel like you're always surrounded by a new team and getting caught up to pace which can be a little stressful at times

review_title: Fraser School - Bright Futures or Unhappy Teachers?
job_title: Teacher, Preschool in Richfield, MN
pros: Fabulous co-teachers, families and children; Pay raises each year; Grants from Target and other local businesses
cons: Had to demand breaks that were required by law several times; Minimal flexibility in scheduling; Hard to obtain time off for medical needs; Volunteers who were not qualified or helpful; High-stress environment; Building falling apart; Mold, rodents, bugs; Cleanliness of facilities; Toys were accrued through donations and were not necessarily in working condition; Ratios of students with special needs to students with typical needs were too high for the support the classrooms received

job_title: Clinical Services Manager in Bloomington, MN
pros:
Working at Fraser feels right.  I love helping our clients, working with other employees, and making a difference. Our clients receiving mental health services are unique, most having autism/intellectual disabilities and a co-occurring mental health disorder.  

Most Fraser programs started because a family came forward and asked for it.  I've worked in our housing areas, and now the adult mental health area.  Fraser builds on strengths of employees works to engage employees in discussions and decisions when possible.
cons: Fraser mental health clinics are not private practice.  I think when some therapists start here they are looking for more freedom to do what they want.  However, this is also a positive because clinicians can spend time doing interventions with clients and less time with the administration side of therapy.

job_title: Children's Mentor Targeted Case Manager II in Coon Rapids, MN
pros: My role as a childrens mental health case manager is salaried and has tons of flexibility and control over my schedule. Free and required supervision (speaking for the clinical and case management departments not sure about residential or school staff.) Upward mobility, if you are willing to change departments.  401k gift contributions for employees after one year even if you don't personally contribute anything. Plenty of females in leadership roles.
cons: Mostly white and under 40 work force ( both describe me)  Benefits aren't as good as other non profits (high deductible bcbs plans are the only option, no employer paid short term disability, no paid parental leave.) Some departments experience high turn over and staffing shortages.

job_title: Developmental Trainee in Minneapolis, MN
pros: It was a great job to get my "feet wet" in the non-profit world. It was my first job in this area. I was in college while I worked there. The employees are compassionate and carry Fraser's mission well.
cons: The pay is too low to be competitive. I have often thought I wouldn't mind working for Fraser again (different position now that I have a lot more experience and a degree), however the pay keeps me away. Fraser is such a good organization. They have really expanded, you would think they would be able to treat their employees to at least a competitive pay. It's really unfortunate.

review_title: Honestly, worst job I’ve ever had.
job_title: Behavior Technician in Coon Rapids, MN
pros: Get to work with kids, gain experience in autism, Work side by side with behavior practitioners, learn about ABA. Coworkers are usually more helpful than supervisors.
cons: Constantly hit in the face, not told about the physical aspect of the job, supervisors suck- they expect you to know everything about ABA and figure things out on your own after asking multiple times for help. The pay sucks, for having a bachelors you should be getting paid more to work with children who have autism.

review_title: Amazing place to make an impact!
job_title: Human Resources Representative in Richfield, MN
pros:
Working at Fraser allows me to make a positive impact on those in our community. The work culture is supportive, engaging and fun, all while keeping our clients at the heart of what we do. I look forward to coming to work every day!

There are a variety of career paths, with opportunities for growth within departments, as well as across the organization. I am surrounded my passionate coworkers, who encourage my development on a regular basis.
cons:
While I am very satisfied in my current position, my particular role doesn't involve client interaction, which I miss. 

Thankfully, Fraser offers great opportunities to get into the community (example, the Fraser Walk for Autism!)

review_title: I couldn't be happier anywhere else!
job_title: Executive Administrative in Richfield, MN
pros:
The culture at Fraser is amazing. Everyone is driven to provide the best care to our clients and make a difference in the lives of others. I have a reason to get up and go to work every day because I feel like I am important part of the process!
Fraser has Career Ladders which are a great tool to see how you can move up in your field.  Generous benefits, PTO and work-life balance top it all off. I couldn't be happier here!
cons: I didn't move to Fraser earlier!

job_title: DSP in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Not all homes are the same, clients were great, outside support services great. Great nursing staff.
cons: Were not honest when interviewing about the position.  Had good policies in place, but never backed up their staff in crisis situations, passed the buck. Rushed in training, due to lack of staff. Lots of gossiping among peers, no accountability. If short staffed, seemed like they got desperate and would hire any one.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Extremely caring and compassionate place to work. Tons of career ladders for people to move up. this is not a place to just work but a place to fulfill your destiny in saving lives of others!
cons: Cannot pay what government or for-profits pay but makes up for it in benefits and culture.

review_title: I am so impressed by this organization!
job_title: Marketing in Richfield, MN
pros: Lots of organizations say they are family friendly and have a work/life balance, but this is the first organization I've seen do it right. They also offer great career ladders and competitive salaries that allow you to keep growing with the organization. Executive leadership is smart, solid, and business savvy. This is a truly innovative organization that has built a strong reputation for being the best in treating autism and mental health issues. I highly recommend working here.
cons: I don't see any negatives.

job_title: Client Service Coordinator in Richfield, MN
pros: On my first day, I was welcomed by friendly smiles, followed by a welcome sign at my desk signed by everyone in the department. From there forward, I have felt appreciated and respected by my coworkers and supervisors. It is rewarding to work for a company which recognizes their employees and works together to help our families and individuals live the quality life they deserve.
cons: You have to use PTO hours for holidays, but you accumulate hours quickly, which roll over from year to year.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Richfield, MN
pros:
-Excellent work life balance
-Get to make a difference everyday
-Awesome coworkers and team
-Fun work and projects
-Supervisor/Team has my best interests and growth at heart
-26 days of PTO
-Growth and advancement clearly defined and obtainable
- Amazing values
-Fraser keeps growing, so more children & families are being served, and more positive change affected every day I work here! Which also means opportunities to grow
cons: It's a non-profit, so low pay is expected, but Fraser makes up for it through appreciating their employees, work life balance, and benefits/PTO

job_title: Mental Health Practitioner II in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Co-workers to vent to. Amazing children and families.
cons: Terrible management who treats their employees with little respect. Limited cultural competency in the upper management who do not put client needs ahead of billing and money. Zero flexibility in scheduling and very few advancement opportunities.  Overall incompetent in running a large non-profit.

job_title: Clinical Services Manager in Coon Rapids, MN
pros: I love working at Fraser.  I have worked for Fraser for 8+ years.  I love the culture and focus on the clients.  I would recommend working at Fraser.  Fraser has provided me the opportunity to use my skills as a clinician, and to become a Clinical Services Manager.
cons: I have worked for a non-profit for all of my life except for 3 years.

job_title: Mental Health Practitioner II in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
Working with clients is rewarding
Staff who provide direct client care are supportive of one another
cons:
Salaried positions consistently require 45+ hour work weeks
Never fully staffed, with minimal support from management
High turn-over for most positions

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Richfield, MN
pros: Amszing services for the communities they serve, Collaborative environment, opportunity to work with very experienced professionals, offers an environment that fosters career growth
cons: Not necessarily a con but because of the services provided there can be a lot of change at times, this is also a pro in that they keep on top of trends in the market and respond accordingly and you get to be a part of that change!

job_title: Marketing Specialist in Richfield, MN
pros: Amazing opportunities to build relationships with coworkers and clients/families, really feel like you're making a difference, Fraser is a place that has a service for everyone even those who haven't been a good fit at other clinics/schools
cons: Management has many jobs spread across locations, case loads can feel overwhelming

job_title: Mental Health Practitioner in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
Coworkers were pretty great
Case load was not too big for MHP I
The clients were great to work with
Had decent PTO
cons:
Upper management treats it like a business, and not like we matter we employees
Didn't get help when it was asked for, in regards to behaviors/working with clients

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Richfield, MN
pros: Meeting and helping clients is rewarding.  Fraser employees are friendly and fun.  Fraser cares about employees and families.  I look forward to coming into work every day.  There is routine but also something new every day.  Fraser is an amazing non-profit company to work for.
cons: There is not always enough work to keep busy during the slower moments in the day.

review_title: A Wonderful place to work with great coworkers!
job_title: Senior Coordinator in Richfield, MN
pros: I enjoy working for a company that helps so many children and families.  We have so many resources to offer.  I love the people I work with and there are many  managers and leaders who are supportive.
cons: It is hard work but is so rewarding!  I can't imagine a career where I wasn't helping people.

review_title: Fraser has a great mission and could be a great company to work at however upper management is clearly falling apart.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
Flexible schedule 
Non profit 
Great CO workers 
Decent benefits 
Independent work
cons:
Management
Staff don't get disiplined when appropriate
Lack of training and accountability 
Lots of gossip
People who suck up to management move up

job_title: Mental Health Practitioner II in Eden Prairie, MN
pros: Wonderful co-workers, a much needed service for children and families, lots of client contact and experience.
cons: Training was rushed and lacking.  Raises barely make a dent.

review_title: Great place to work, company that really cares about employees and clients
job_title: PCA/DSP in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Very helpful supervisors, promote from within, good communication, work with you to find a good fit, many opportunities available for extra hours and different experiences
cons: Challenging clients, feel like you are on your own sometimes instead of part of a company when doing home care work

review_title: Love my job but would appreciate more support
job_title: Program Assistant in Mahtomedi, MN
pros: There is a great rapport between day treatment staff and it allows us to work seamlessly together which is wholly necessary when working with children.
cons: Extremely poor communication from higher ups down to CPAs, and very little support during large changes made to staffing or various other stressful situations.

job_title: Program Manager in Richfield, MN
pros: I love that in every decision that is made, the client is at the center.
cons: Ever changing...this is not a con to Fraser, but health care in general is changing so fast and Fraser is working hard to stay ahead

job_title: Direct Support Professional in Minneapolis, MN
pros: It's a place you can be proud to say you work for. The employees genuinely care about the welfare of the clients. They emphasize training throughout employment. Asking for time off is not difficult, and they are in general extremely flexible.
cons: As with many human services, the pay is low.

job_title: Vice President in Richfield, MN
pros: Strategic leadership, strong financially, pay for performance, investment in employee development, fast growing, career ladders.  Passionate culture.  Fair. Genuine.
cons: If someone does not like change, this could be a poor fit. We are growing so fast, we need to be adaptable.

job_title: Behavior Technician in Coon Rapids, MN
pros:
Very well organized, step by step, one on one behavior intervention.
Opportunities for professional development.
Some health benefits.
cons:
Very low hourly pay. 
Distant, critical administration.

job_title: Developmental Trainee in Richfield, MN
pros: Flexible schedule, can do half or full days morning or afternoons in the day treatment program.
cons: Didn't feel like management cared very much about their employees and there was not enough training provided for staff. Additionally, the pay was not very good considering how hard the work is.

job_title: Volunteer Program Manager in Richfield, MN
pros: Fraser promotes professional development and growth with their employees. They are a supportive employer that fosters a strong team environment.
cons: It's tough work and Fraser expects a lot out of you.  However, the way they challenge their employees promotes individual growth and development.

job_title: Human Resources Coordinator in Richfield, MN
pros: I felt very supported in my role at Fraser. Everyone was very kind in offering help and guidance which I very much appreciated.
cons: There were no negative aspects while working for Fraser.

job_title: Mental Health Practitioner in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Lots of training and nice coworkers/supervisors
cons: Overwhelming, understaffed, poor job at explaining what you'll actually do in the position until you're there

job_title: Teacher in Richfield, MN
pros: Great kids and kind families
cons: There isn't enough pto and they make it hard to balance your home and work life, I wouldnt recommend it if you have other things in life to do.

review_title: Good entry level experience, but not interested in doing forever
job_title: Clinical Operations Coordinator in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Great coworkers and culture, great cause and company objectives

job_title: in Minneapolis, MN

review_title: Case Manager/Senior Case Manager/Case Management Supervisor
